motive_patterns.risk_escalation: Certain disappearance categories indicate higher risk, especially 'Endangered' and 'Involuntary' which correlate with danger, abduction, or physical vulnerability.
decision_factors: Age strongly influences how missing persons are coded (majority of cases are juveniles).
Juvenile category overwhelmingly dominates missing person entries (over 330,000 out of 533,936).
Involuntary (abduction/kidnapping) cases are extremely rare compared to runaway and endangered categories.
Race distribution differs by age and category, affecting reporting and classification patterns.

behavioral_indicators: Most cases do not involve criminal abduction (less than 1% were stranger abductions).
Runaway patterns dominate the dataset (95% of all entries using MPC field).
High-volume disappearance among teens indicates social, family, or environmental stressors rather than offender-driven grooming.

temporal_patterns.duration_patterns: Records remain active indefinitely until resolved; disappearance periods vary widely and are not recorded in NCIC statistics.
temporal_patterns.escalation_timeline: Runaway cases constitute rapid-onset disappearances, whereas endangered or involuntary classifications reflect escalating safety concerns.

risk_factors: Being under age 18 is the strongest risk factor for being reported missing (349,557 entries in 2024)
Youth age 20 and under account for 368,196 out of 533,936 entries (~69%)
Runaway behavior is the dominant risk factor (accounting for 95% of cases where MPC was used)
Racial disparities in reporting (e.g., Black youth significantly overrepresented in juvenile missing categories)
High-risk categories include Endangered, Involuntary, and Disability marking individuals vulnerable to harm

movement_patterns.typical_distances: Not specified; NCIC does not track distance traveled.
destination_types: Runaways tend to remain within local/regional areas (based on historical behavioral research, not NCIC data).
Involuntary/kidnapping cases represent a tiny proportion (0.1% stranger abductions).

training_examples.narrative: A 15-year-old juvenile is reported missing and categorized as a runaway. No signs of foul play. This aligns with the statistical majority of 2024 missing juvenile entries.
A child under age 10 is classified as 'Endangered' due to circumstances indicating immediate physical danger. This reflects the NCIC endangered category.
A missing person record is coded 'Involuntary,' indicating circumstances suggesting abduction or kidnapping. These represent a very small portion of NCIC entries (less than 1%).
